answers.suggestion: Check power cable, power supply, or power button.

text: Is there visible damage to the cable or connectors?

answers.suggestion: Replace the damaged cable or connector. Physical damage can lead to signal loss, intermittent connectivity, or complete failure. Replace the component and retest the link.

text: Is light received on both ends?

answers.suggestion: Use a fiber tester, visual fault locator, or infrared card to confirm light transmission at both ends. Clean connectors if needed and recheck.

text: Is there link light on both the end-device and the switch port?

answers.suggestion: Check GBIC seating, patch cable connection, try cleaning fiber interfaces, or try replacing the GBIC/SFP.

text: Is the GBIC/SFP seated properly on both sides?

answers.suggestion: Reseat the GBIC/SFP on both the switch and the end-device. Wait a few seconds and check link status again.

text: Is the patch cable properly connected at both ends? (Verify click)

answers.suggestion: Reconnect the patch cable securely on both ends and check link status.

text: Is the fiber correctly patched through the patch panel hops?

answers.suggestion: Verify patch panel labeling and ensure the fiber path is correctly routed end-to-end. Correct any mispatching and retest the link. (relabel if needed!)

text: Are you using the correct type of GBIC/SFP for this port and cable?

answers.suggestion: Verify GBIC/SFP compatibility with the switch and the type of fiber or copper cable. Replace with a supported module if needed.

text: Did you clean the fiber patch cable connectors?

answers.suggestion: Clean the fiber patch cable connectors using a fiber cleaning tool and retest link status.

text: Did you clean the patch panel port?

answers.suggestion: Clean the patch panel fiber port using a LC cleaning tool and retest the link.

text: Did you clean the GBIC/SFP module?

answers.suggestion: Clean the GBIC/SFP module with a MPO/LC cleaner, then retest connectivity.

text: Did you perform a loopback test towards up?

answers.suggestion: Insert a loopback plug at the end-device side and check if signal is received back. Use diagnostics or link lights to verify. If passed, route is probably clear.

text: Did you perform a loopback test towards down?

answers.suggestion: Perform a loopback test on the switch-side port using a loopback adapter. If the link comes up, it confirms the port is operational and connectivity downstream is likely clear.

text: Did you replace the GBIC/SFP module?

answers.suggestion: Replace the GBIC/SFP module with a known-good, compatible one. Even seated modules can fail due to wear, manufacturing faults, or static damage.

text: Did you try replacing the patch cable (fiber or copper/DAC)?

answers.suggestion: Replace the patch cable with a known-good one of the same type and check link status. If the issue persists, check with Network Engineering to verify whether the port is operational or administratively shut.

text: Did you try a different patch panel port?

answers.suggestion: Try connecting to a different patch panel port if available, to rule out a damaged or dirty port. Before doing so, check with an ID team member to confirm port availability, ensure proper patching, and relabel if needed.

text: Did you try a different switch port?

answers.suggestion: Try connecting the cable to a different available switch port to rule out a faulty interface. If you're unsure or the port is restricted, reach out to Network Engineering for approval before proceeding.

text: Is the switch port shut (operational/admin down)? Poll device first

answers.suggestion: Verify on NSM if the port is shut (operational/admin down) and if so, escalate to Network Engineering for further validation.
